'''Muthu Alagappan''' (born c. 1990)<ref name="Mercury News: cult status"/><ref name="Forbes 2012 30 Under 30: Sports"/> is a medical student known for his [[National Basketball Association|professional basketball]] [[analytics]].
== Early life ==
Alagappan was born in [[Crewe, England]]<ref name="Tamil Culture interview"/> and raised in [[Houston|Houston, Texas]].<ref name="Forbes 2012 30 Under 30: Sports"/> He is of [[Indian people|Indian]] heritage.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> He graduated from [[Stanford University]] in 2012 with a degree in biomedical engineering.<ref name="TEDx Spokane"/><ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> {{as of|2013}}, he is a medical student at [[Stanford School of Medicine]].<ref name="TEDx Spokane"/><ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> Alagappan is a longtime [[Houston Rockets]] fan.<ref name="Forbes 2012 30 Under 30: Sports"/>
== Basketball analytics ==
Alagappan was hired as an [[intern]] with [[Ayasdi]], a [[big data]] [[startup company|startup]] in [[Palo Alto, California]], through Stanford's [[Mayfield Fellows Program]], where he was hired to do sales.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> He tested the company's software on basketball stats and called the output "the true positions of the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]]".<ref name="Mercury News: cult status"/> The [[topological data analysis]] mapped similarities between NBA players and identified 13 distinct [[Basketball positions|positions of play]], as opposed to the traditional five.<ref name="NYT: Trading Small Forward"/> Those traditional positions, such as [[Power forward (basketball)|power forward]] and [[shooting guard]], have become ambiguous and outmoded as a result of the increased variety of player styles categorized by them.<ref name="NYT: Trading Small Forward"/> Alagappan's method groups professional basketball players by statistical strengths and places them into the new positional model.<ref name="Forbes 2012 30 Under 30: Sports"/>
He started with a collection of seven basic statistics ([[Assist (basketball)|assists]], [[Block (basketball)|blocks]], [[Assist (basketball)|fouls]], [[Point (basketball)|points]], [[Rebound (basketball)|rebounds]], [[Steal (basketball)|steals]], and [[Turnover (basketball)|turnovers]]) from [[Yahoo! Sports]] on every NBA player from the previous season and adjusted the stats for time in play.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> The software grouped the players into color-coded nodes and connected them with lines that represented statistical similarities.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> Alagappan had expected the software to create five groups of nodes by statistical advantages, which would each represent a position of play, but the software instead returned 13 node groups representing 13 mathematically-described positions.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> The assignments compare player statistics and not individual style.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> Originally unconfident in his results, he explored the data on his own for a week before sharing his findings with his bosses and basketball statisticians including [[Ken Pomeroy]], who replied in encouragement.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> He then applied and was accepted to speak at the 2012 [[MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference]].<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> By May 2012, at least four NBA teams and one [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] team had contacted Ayasdi about using their technology.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/>
The method is intended to change existing basketball team composition paradigms to help NBA teams win championships.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> Alagappan used [[Devin Ebanks]] of the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] as an example, whom Alagappan considered promising for his classification as a "scoring rebounder" alongside [[Carmelo Anthony]] and [[Dirk Nowitzki]] despite a subpar season record.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> [[GQ]] reported that Ebanks would come to fulfill the model's forecast in following games for six weeks when two other players sat out and Ebanks [[Starting lineup#Basketball|started]] games.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/> While the model couldn't have predicted [[Linsanity]], when given college basketball stats, it was able to determine three players most similar to Lin in college, of which two were already drafted in the NBA.<ref name="Wired: Analytics Reveal 13"/> The forecasting is expected to improve with the growth of the data set.<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/>
His data-driven analysis has been well received. He won the top prize in the "Evolution of Sports" category at the 2012 [[MIT Sloan Sports Analytics Conference]].<ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/><ref name="Mercury News: cult status"/> ''[[GQ]]'' called his work "a new frontier for the NBA" and "Muthuball", an allusion to [[Sabermetrics|Moneyball]], [[baseball]] [[statistical analysis]] known for revolutionizing the sport.<ref name="Mercury News: cult status"/> ''[[Forbes]]'' included him in their 2012 "30 Under 30" list of influential people in the sports industry.<ref name="Forbes 2012 30 Under 30: Sports"/><ref name="Mercury News: cult status"/> His work has received mention in ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[ESPN]], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', and ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''.<ref name="Mercury News: cult status"/><ref name="GQ: Muthuball"/>
Rob Mahoney of [[The New York Times]] called the model "a novel execution of a productive thought", but cited the "one-of-a-kind" catch-all position and the substantial number of players categorized within it as weak points.<ref name="NYT: Trading Small Forward"/> [[ESPN]] [[TrueHoop]]'s Jim Calvan criticized Alagappan's Sloan presentation for its lack of data showing how team reconfiguration to cover the 13 positions results in more wins.<ref name="ESPN TrueHoop: Solving"/>
